prior_works.title: The hippocampus as a spatial map. Preliminary evidence from unit activity in the freely-moving rat
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that hippocampal neurons encode spatial location, providing the substrate whose tuning properties this paper analyzes to link spatial resolution to contextual capacity.

prior_works.title: The effects of changes in the environment on the spatial firing of hippocampal complex-spike cells in the rat
prior_works.authors: Robert U. Muller; Joseph L. Kubie
prior_works.role: Experimental characterization of remapping across environments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that place cells remap with environmental changes, motivating the notion of distinct context representations whose number (capacity) this work quantifies as a function of place-field statistics.

prior_works.title: Attractor dynamics in the hippocampal representation of the local environment
prior_works.authors: T. J. Wills; C. Lever; F. Cacucci; N. Burgess; J. O'Keefe
prior_works.role: Attractor dynamics and global remapping evidence
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed abrupt, attractor-like transitions between hippocampal maps, supporting a discrete-context view that underlies the paper’s definition of contextual capacity (how many distinct maps can be supported).

prior_works.title: Attractor neural networks storing multiple spatial maps in the hippocampus
prior_works.role: Theoretical capacity of multiple stored spatial maps
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a formal framework for how many spatial maps the hippocampus can store, directly inspiring the present analysis of contextual capacity and its dependence on tuning properties.

prior_works.title: Geometric determinants of the place fields of hippocampal neurons
prior_works.role: Determinants and statistics of place-field size/shape
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Linked environmental geometry to place-field size and layout, supplying the empirical constraints on field statistics that the paper uses in its geometric population-code calculations.

prior_works.title: An information-theoretic approach to deciphering the hippocampal code
prior_works.authors: William E. Skaggs; Bruce L. McNaughton; K. M. Gothard
prior_works.role: Information-theoretic analysis of spatial coding accuracy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Quantified how tuning properties determine spatial information, a cornerstone for the paper’s tradeoff showing that finer spatial resolution reduces the capacity to represent multiple contexts.

prior_works.title: Grid cells generate an analog error-correcting code for the hippocampus
prior_works.authors: Sharad S. Sreenivasan; Ila R. Fiete
prior_works.role: Coding-theoretic view of navigation codes and capacity–precision trade-offs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced a code-theoretic framework relating resolution and representational range, conceptually paralleling this paper’s demonstration of a resolution–context capacity tradeoff in place-cell codes.

synthesis_narrative: The key contribution of the paper is a quantitative, geometric account of how hippocampal place-cell tuning properties set a tradeoff between spatial resolution and the number of distinct contexts (maps) that can be represented—its contextual capacity. This builds on the foundational discovery that hippocampal neurons encode position (O’Keefe & Dostrovsky) and the observation that their tuning remaps when environments or cues change (Muller & Kubie). Evidence for abrupt, attractor-like switching between representations (Wills et al.) motivates treating contexts as discrete maps whose number can be analyzed as a capacity problem. Theoretical work on storing multiple spatial maps in attractor networks (Battaglia & Treves) provides a direct precedent for formal capacity calculations, which this paper extends by explicitly incorporating empirically grounded place-field statistics and geometric population-code considerations. Empirical determinants of place-field size and layout (O’Keefe & Burgess) and information-theoretic analyses linking tuning to spatial information (Skaggs et al.) supply the critical link between field width/tiling and localization precision used in the tradeoff derivation. Finally, coding-theoretic perspectives from grid-cell models (Sreenivasan & Fiete) establish the conceptual template that precision and representational range are coupled, an idea the present work adapts to hippocampal place codes to show that increasing positional resolution necessarily diminishes the capacity for distinct contextual remappings. Together, these works converge to enable a principled, quantitative theory of how the structure of place fields governs the balance between “place” precision and “space” of contexts.
